Award.AwardTitle: Institutionalizing Undergraduate Research throughout the Chemistry Laboratory Curriculum
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by investigating the impact of multi-year course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) in an undergraduate chemistry laboratory curriculum. Developing opportunities to engage students in discovery-based science experiences is a national priority. CUREs achieve this goal by replacing traditional “cook-book” laboratory activities with authentic research experiences. Although CUREs have been developed in a variety of contexts, most research on their effectiveness examines individual courses. This project intends to advance knowledge about CUREs by investigating how a multi-year, sequenced CURE curriculum affects student learning. This project will transform the entire laboratory curriculum to center on undergraduate research. It is expected that this transformation will improve student recruitment, retention, and subsequent participation in other research experiences, especially for students from groups that are not yet equitably represented in STEM. These efforts will also provide a case study of evidence-based change to the chemistry laboratory curriculum that is designed to complement efforts to reform the chemistry lecture curriculum.

CURE curricula will be developed in four chemistry laboratory courses at the State University of New York College (SUNY) at Geneseo, a primarily undergraduate institution. The CUREs will be introduced in participants’ first-year laboratory courses and be scaffolded in a multi-year sequence spanning a four year laboratory curriculum including general, organic, and inorganic chemistry, plus a senior capstone course. This project differs from previous CURE examples in that it will engage students in learning research skills during all four years of the undergraduate chemistry program, instead of just a single experience. The specific STEM education research questions will explore the impacts of a multi-year, sequenced CURE curriculum on student learning outcomes, student understanding of the research process, and students’ ability to carry out a meaningful research project. These outcomes will be investigated in collaboration with an external project evaluator using both indirect assessments of student perceptions of their learning gains from a nationally validated CURE survey and direct assessment through comparison of students’ course grades, laboratory assignments and exams, and participation in other research experiences before and after the curriculum change. Expected outcomes of the project include a better prepared STEM work force, greater persistence in pursuing post-baccalaureate education, a more diverse STEM community, and improved STEM educational practices. Results from this project will be disseminated locally in professional development workshops for STEM instructors, via a SUNY-wide online platform, and through presentations at regional conferences and publications in STEM education journals. This project was submitted in response to the "Dear Colleague Letter: Stimulating Participation from Institutions New to the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources Program: (NSF 20-034)" and is funded by the NSF IUSE: EHR program, which supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The Institutionalizing Undergraduate Research throughout the Chemistry Laboratory Curriculum project (NSF Award #2021281) sought (1) to develop a novel chemistry curriculum based on course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs), (2) to implement the new curriculum at the State University of New York, College at Geneseo (Geneseo), and (3) to measure its impacts on student learning.

CUREs are an inquiry-based approach to laboratory classes that seek to extend the benefits of undergraduate research (a recognized high impact practice) to large audiences by replacing traditional ‘cookbook’ laboratory procedures with authentic, hypothesis-driven research problems, with unknown results that are of interest outside the classroom. Most CUREs that have been developed and studied to date are stand-alone, one-semester experiences. Our project was unique because it was designed to extend across all four years of students’ undergraduate coursework and to cover multiple chemistry subdisciplines, enabling one of the first investigations of potential benefits in multi-course CURE models. It was anticipated that this approach would improve student learning, student retention, and student preparedness for science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) careers, critical national needs that are required in order to maintain and advance a globally competitive STEM workforce.

New CURE curricula were developed and implemented in four different chemistry laboratory classes at Geneseo (general chemistry, organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, and a senior capstone). The research projects included production and characterization of model biosensor systems, method optimization in green chemistry organic reactions, and investigation of novel antimicrobial organometallic compounds. 8 faculty members and 221 unique students participated in 254 CURE experiences during the four-year project lifetime; results were disseminated at 14 conference presentations and one academic research article, with additional publications in preparation.

We found that the new CURE curriculum was equally effective as traditional curricula in terms of student learning associated with content knowledge (as measured by assignment scores pre- and post-intervention). However, CUREs were significantly better than traditional curricula in terms of affective learning gains (eg, their attitudes and dispositions about science, themselves, and learning) and furthermore, that these gains could be further increased with additional CURE experiences. For example, we determined self-efficacy (a student’s belief in their ability to complete a task) was increased in a statistically significant manner with each CURE experience, whereas other variables (number of traditional classes, demographic factors, etc) had no effect. Retention of new chemistry majors at Geneseo increased from 32% pre-intervention to 55% post-intervention. All these data support the conclusion that multi-course CURE curricula produce unique benefits compared to stand-alone CURE experiences and suggest directions by which CUREs may be implemented and further improved to extend their benefits.
